message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. It can be calculated as the sum of residual volume and expiratory reserve volume. In this case, FRC is 1700 mL + 1500 mL = 3200 mL, which corresponds to option (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation. It is equal to the residual volume plus the expiratory reserve volume. Therefore, the FRC in this patient is 1700 mL + 1500 mL = 3200 mL, which corresponds to answer choice (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. It can be calculated by adding the residual volume (RV) and the expiratory reserve volume (ERV). FRC = RV + ERV = 1700 mL + 1500 mL = 3200 mL, so the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a normal expiration. FRC is equal to residual volume (RV) plus expiratory reserve volume (ERV). In this case, FRC = 1700 mL (RV) + 1500 mL (ERV) = 3200 mL, so the correct answer is (B).
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity can be calculated by adding residual volume and expiratory reserve volume, which is 1700 + 1500 = 3200 mL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. FRC can be calculated by adding residual volume (RV) and expiratory reserve volume (ERV). In this case, FRC = RV + ERV = 1700 mL + 1500 mL = 3200 mL (Option B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air that remains in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration. To calculate FRC, we can use the formula FRC = RV + ERV. Given that residual volume (RV) is 1700 mL and expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is 1500 mL, we add those two values to get FRC = 3200 mL (option B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. It can be calculated by adding the residual volume (RV) to the expiratory reserve volume (ERV). In this case, FRC = RV + ERV = 1700 mL + 1500 mL = 3200 mL. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. FRC can be calculated by adding residual volume (RV) and expiratory reserve volume (ERV). FRC = RV + ERV = 1700 mL + 1500 mL = 3200 mL (option B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation (i.e. expiratory reserve volume + residual volume). Using the provided information, FRC can be calculated by adding the residual volume (1700 mL) and the expiratory reserve volume (1500 mL), which equals 3200 mL (option B).
